;;S;;ome徒步旅行者认为最后一英里是最难的：所有的水泡和累积的疼痛在最后减缓了进展。其他人发誓这是最简单的，因为终点线就在眼前。对于美联储来说，将通胀率拉回到 2% 目标的最后一英里既容易又困难。从某种意义上说，这很容易，因为央行已经八个月没有调整利率，而是让之前的紧缩政策发挥作用。很难，因为等待通胀消退的时间感觉相当漫长。

;价格压力的缓慢缓解和美国持续的经济活力引发了关于美联储是否可能因此在反通胀旅程的最后一英里制定更加激进的方针的争论。政策制定者已电报称，他们今年将降息三个四分之一个百分点。但自那以后，一些重要的通胀指标似乎一直停留在 3-4% 左右，而失业率则保持在 4% 以下。因此，3 月 20 日结束的货币政策会议面临的一个大问题是，美联储是否可能将降息预期削减至两次。最终，央行（或者更准确地说，是其利率制定委员会中票数中位数的成员）选择维持 2024 年三次降息的预期，但将 2025 年的预测从 2025 年下调至三次。四.

;通胀指标的重大差距有助于解释美联储坚持今年计划的理由。对通货膨胀持续存在的担忧很大程度上源于最近的消费者价格指数读数。剔除波动性较大的食品和能源成本后，“核心”CPI 在 2022 年大部分时间和 2023 年初有所放缓，但自去年 6 月以来增速有所加快。 1 月和 2 月，通胀率均以约 0.4% 的月度涨幅，如果这一增速持续一整年，将导致年度通胀率达到 5% 左右，这对于美联储来说太高了。在这种情况下，美国央行官员担心的不是降息，而是是否恢复加息。

;

;然而，尽管投资者和评论员倾向于强调<小>;CPI;，<小>;;在很大程度上是因为它是每个月的第一个通胀数据点，央行的重点是一个单独的指标：个人消费支出价格指数，几周后就会出来。核心;PCE;价格表现较好。尽管它们在一月份升温，但过去半年的年化增速与美联储 2% 的通胀目标完全一致。这有助于让央行官员相信他们可以相对较快地开始降息。

;是什么导致;CPI;-;PCE;差异？ ;CPI;更加刚性，其组成部分每年都会调整； ;PCE;实际上每个月都会调整，例如反映消费者是否用更便宜的苹果替代更贵的橙子。随着时间的推移，这会导致;PCE;价格增长略有下降。不同的权重今年也产生了很大的影响。住房约占;CPI ;篮子的三分之一，但仅占;PCE ;的15%，而居高不下的租金使;CPI ;持续走高。还有其他差异。例如，根据一组固定航线的价格，机票价格推高了 2 月份的;CPI;。考虑实际飞行距离的 ;PCE; 较低。

;美联储的另一个问题是它希望最终走向何方。在理想的世界中，央行官员将引导充分就业、稳定通胀的经济达到所谓的中性利率，即货币政策既不扩张也不紧缩的水平。事实上，尽管无法观察到中性利率，但美联储仍试图以中性利率为目标，其政策制定者每季度都会写下他们的估计。自 2019 年以来，他们的实际预测中位数为 0.5%（即联邦基金利率为 2.5%，;个人消费支出;通胀率为 2%）。

;

;这种情况已经改变，尽管是难以察觉的。美联储新的长期利率预测中值上调至 2.6%，意味着实际中性利率为 0.6%。这听起来可能是一个微不足道的学术差异。但这是央行思考大流行后增长的核心，特别是它是否认为利率应该持续走高，以避免经济过热，这可能是由于生产率提高或政府过度支出造成的。官员们似乎正在倾向于这种观点，尽管鲍威尔先生反对根据长期利率的上升趋势得出任何结论。

;;;;阿纳姆伯格斯动物园的年轻雄性黑猩猩;又打起来了。他们绕着岛屿奔跑，露出牙齿，尖叫着。特别是其中有两个人一直在战斗，直到一个人最终获胜，另一个人失败。最后，他们显然在生闷气，高高地站在同一棵树上相距甚远的树枝上。然后，年轻的弗朗斯·德瓦尔（Frans de Waal）正在观察他们的战争以完成他的论文，他看到了一些令人惊讶的事情。一个人向另一个人伸出了手，仿佛在说：“我们和解吧。”一分钟后，他们就荡到了树的主叉处，在那里拥抱并亲吻。

;

;他毫不犹豫地称此为那是什么：和解。更重要的是，如果团队想要凝聚力和生存下去，这一点至关重要。然而，这个词激怒了他的导师。在 20 世纪 70 年代中期，研究灵长类动物主要是记录暴力、攻击性和自私。这些就是人类应该超越的“动物本能”。动物没有感情或理解力让过去的事就让它过去。在黑猩猩岛上，一切都是牙齿和爪子。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;但是 de Waal 博士看到了那只手伸出来，这永远改变了他的工作。他决定向科学怀疑论者提供他们所需的证据——数百次实验、数小时的视频和大量数据——以证明人类感受到的每一种情感，其他灵长类动物也能感受到。当他看着黑猩猩的眼睛时，他的目光充满了聪明和自信。当达尔文看到被挠痒痒的黑猩猩大笑时，他也有同样的感觉，就像他的孩子们一样。他最狭隘的对手是 20 世纪的行为主义者，他们将动物简化为机器，将动物的笑声简化为“喘息声”。

;

;几十年来，他主要在佐治亚州埃默里大学担任灵长类动物行为学教授，并用他面无表情的荷兰方式发表充满笑话的;TED;演讲，将他的想法融入了科学主流。他仔细地选择了自己的物种：黑猩猩、倭黑猩猩和卷尾猴，前两种与人类的 ;DNA; 构成仅相差 1.5%。他对黑猩猩很熟悉，因为在动物园工作之前，他曾与两只住在奈梅亨大学心理学系的黑猩猩成为朋友。倭黑猩猩引起了他的兴趣，因为它们几乎没有黑猩猩所承认的攻击性，而且几乎一直都很和平，可以做爱，而不是战争。 （他自己也有点嬉皮士的气质，在 20 世纪 70 年代几乎和倭黑猩猩一样毛茸茸的，他对此很感兴趣。）如果他能让人们相信，他们更好的本能——利他主义、合作、缔造和平——就像他们与生俱来的那样，会怎么样？暴力是，“动物”也是吗？

;

;公平的概念就是一个很好的例子。其他灵长类动物也要求平等的待遇和奖励，他的证据被记录在视频中，并迅速传播开来。两只卷尾猴被关在相邻的笼子里，并被赋予相同的任务，将石头交给研究人员。起初，两人都得到了一片水黄瓜作为奖励。但随后有人得到了一颗葡萄的奖励。被轻视的猴子注意到了，感到不安。当这种情况再次发生时，猴子发疯了，把它的一片黄瓜扔出笼子，摇动栅栏，并竭尽全力从外面抓起那碗葡萄。占领华尔街抗议活动就在那里。

;
;
;
;
;< /div>;
;

;政治是他的研究对象所擅长的领域，而且以令人惊讶的微妙方式。野蛮行为在黑猩猩的领导力竞争中没有发挥作用。相反，他们通过赠送食物或某些女性的恩惠来达成交易并培养联盟。他指出，群体中的雄性领袖并不总是最大或最强的，但最擅长策划。简而言之，黑猩猩马基雅维利。他在《黑猩猩政治》（1982 年）中阐述了这一切，这是他写的 17 本有关灵长类动物行为的畅销书的第一本，傲慢的众议院议长纽特·金里奇 (Newt Gingrich) 宣称所有国会新生都应该阅读这本书。

;

;从 1981 年第一次在威斯康星州定居，到十年后他愉快地搬到佐治亚州的森林，德瓦尔博士本人就拥抱了美国。他为他的学生举办了“猿猴晚会”。美国是推动他的事业的好地方，但它的基础牢固地建立在荷兰圩田上，他小时候在那里钓鱼——不是为了吃他的捕获物，而是为了保存它们并观察它们的生存。尽管他开始关注灵长类动物，但他对动物情感的研究是从火蝾螈和刺鱼开始的。

;

;超越合作，他他喜欢通过展示两只黑猩猩拖着一个沉重的箱子来证明它们无法单独移动，但他也看到了纯粹的利他主义的例子：女族长黑猩猩佩妮，年纪太大了，无法行走，在其他雌性或一群黑猩猩的帮助下穿过围栏，爬上树。男性舔舐战败战士的伤口。他看到雄性在雌性不在时照顾孩子，甚至放慢穿过森林的步伐，让小家伙跟上。同性性行为很常见，什么都可以。不存在不容忍现象。也许最令人感动的是一只名叫 Kuni 的雌性倭黑猩猩的明确同情心，她发现一只受伤的鸟，带着它爬到最高的树顶，展开翅膀鼓励它飞翔。

;

;这样的灵长类动物是否有道德良心​​，更不用说道德确定性了，他对此表示怀疑。他们和人类之间的主要区别在于，人类编造故事，比如伊索寓言，来证明他们的行为合理。有了这样的理由，他们经常试图将自己的道德价值观强加给不同的民族。其他灵长类动物没有尝试，通常只向外群体展示其粗糙的一面。

;

;总结自己的工作，他认为自己已经提出了猿猴起来了一点，把人类打倒了。人类的最高成就仍然存在，比如他喜欢弹奏的钢琴曲，这当然是值得珍惜的。但他同样珍惜新冠病毒 (covid-19) 封锁结束后所看到的一切：人类享受简单的群体团结，看着真实的面孔，互相触摸，这是灵长类动物的本性。 ;■;

;冲突开始时俄罗斯在无人掩护的院子里拥有大约 19,000 门火炮。但其中一些枪支已经生锈了几十年，无法使用。在过去的两年里，许多枪管都被搜查以获取零件：枪管经常被用来更换因发射数千发子弹而磨损的枪管。一位 X 开源情报 (;OSINT;) 分析师（网站上的昵称 Ben）的一项研究表明，在此基础上，仍然可以使用 2,000 门自行火炮和 2,400 门牵引火炮.; ;这些数字是不确定的：很难估计俄罗斯最古老的火炮，<小>;D;-1和<小>;M;-30榴弹炮的数量，回到第二次世界大战，仍然可以使用——或者俄罗斯有多少弹药给他们。但火炮供应的减少，尤其是枪管供应的减少，是一个明显的问题。

;

;很难估计供应减少的速度。乌克兰正在摧毁俄罗斯的火炮：大炮通常驻扎在远离前线的地方，难以清点。乌克兰武装部队声称摧毁了1万多架飞机，但目视确认的数字要少得多。 Oryx 是荷兰的一个 ;OSINT; 分析团队，其估计通常与国家机构的估计相当一致，拥有大约 1,000 张图像。根据从露天库存中撤回装备的速度，X 的;OSINT;分析师表示，乌克兰人已经销毁了大约 5,500 门大炮。一位消息灵通的分析师表示，预计俄罗斯将在 2025 年耗尽石油桶，届时它将需要依靠火箭炮，而这需要更多的爆炸材料供应。

;

;在过去的一年里，乌克兰在摧毁俄罗斯火炮方面变得更加出色（尽管反之亦然）。它的探测系统得到了改进：其盟友提供的反炮兵雷达可以追踪俄罗斯炮弹的来源。充足供应 ;小型神风特攻队无人机;，从距离目标 20 公里的地方发射，可以摧毁俄罗斯的枪支。入侵者可以通过将火炮从前线移至更远的地方，或者完全撤回一些火炮来保护他们的火炮。但这会妨碍他们打击乌克兰人的能力。对于防守者来说，这将带来可喜的缓解。;■;

;

;When Hong Kong was handed back to China by the British in 1997 it was given a mini-constitution, called the Basic Law, and promised “a high degree of autonomy” under the “one country, two systems” model.居民获得了大陆华人无法享有的自由和公民自由。然而该文件的第 23 条却笼罩着这座城市。它要求香港通过国家安全立法，许多人担心这会改变其性质。 When the government tried to push through such a measure in 2003 it sparked large protests and the city's leaders backed down.

;

;The ease with which the measure passed this time around is indicative of just how much has changed in Hong Kong. In recent years, controls on speech, news media, books and culture have grown more stifling, at the behest of the central government. The older security law had already deterred most people with political grievances from attempting to challenge the government. The new one adds to this atmosphere of fear. No big protests are expected in the coming days.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But the speed with which the government moved to pass Article 23 has raised eyebrows.它于1月30日揭晓。随后进行了一次异常简短的公众咨询，并于 2 月 28 日结束。该法案随后迅速通过立法会。一些人认为，这样做的目的是为了让外国观察家措手不及，从而避免受到批评。尽管如此，在委员会阶段审查该法案的立法者仍预计会产生影响。 Bracing for sanctions imposed by Western governments, they have reportedly begun referring to themselves as “martyrs”.

;

;Hong Kong officials seem to believe any sacrifice would be worth it.他们认为原来的安全法有助于给这座城市带来和平与繁荣，并认为新的法律也会产生类似的积极影响。李显龙称这一时刻是“历史性的”，并补充说政府“辜负了国家的信任，没有让中央政府失望”。 If the people of Hong Kong disagree, they will have to say so quietly.;■;

;;“W;;e are genuinely; very satisfied,” declared President Javier Milei of Argentina on local radio, after inflation in February fell more than expected to 13%. That, however, is the monthly figure. Over the past year it has added up to 276%—the highest in the world. Inflation of just 8% annually has rattled politics in richer countries. That Mr Milei, with some justification, saw fit to celebrate 13% monthly inflation shows what an utter economic mess he inherited, and how much he has left to do to fix it.

;

;Mr Milei, an irascible outsider and ;self-described “anarcho-capitalist”;, campaigned while brandishing a chainsaw and promising to slash spending. On December 10th he took over a bloated state running vast budget deficits financed by printing money. Inflation was rampant; the value of the peso in the drain. The government owed $263bn to foreign creditors, including $43bn to the ;IMF;, but had no dollars whatsoever. Like many Argentine governments, the previous one spent far beyond its means trying to buy popularity, while inventing increasingly absurd temporary macroeconomic fixes (such as heavy price controls) to keep the economy wobbling along.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Milei is trying to steer the country down a dangerously narrow path, discarding those dodgy fixes as he goes.他的基本政治问题是，猛烈攻击建制派和普通政客，他称之为“种姓”的群体，是他受欢迎的支柱。然而，由于其成员在国会中占主导地位，他需要来自它的一些支持来实施深入的改革。 But if he makes too many deals with it he risks his outsider status and thus some popular backing—his only real political asset.

;

;After 100 days he can boast of real economic success.尽管他缺乏国会的支持，但他的受欢迎程度仍在持续上升。如果他能够在明年年底的中期选举之前让公众保持支持，他就可以极大地增强自己的影响力，从而增强他重塑阿根廷经济的能力。但阿根廷人已经深受其苦，可能会更早地抛弃他。 That would be a blow to radical reformers worldwide.

;

;Start with his economic successes.为了表明不会再印钞，米莱先生痴迷于实现预算盈余，这意味着政府征税超过支出。 He says he will achieve a surplus (before interest payments) this year of 2% of ;GDP;, a huge change from a 3% deficit last year.一月和二月，政府均实现了月度盈余，这是十多年来的首次。为此，它在一定程度上使用了米莱先生的电锯：削减能源和交通补贴、向各省的转移支付和资本支出。 It also relied on another tool;: la licuadora;, the blender. Raising spending by less than inflation is a reduction in real terms, known in Argentina as ;licuación;. Spending on contributory pensions, the single biggest budget item, fell almost 40% in real terms compared with the first two months of last year.

;

;政府还采取了另外两项重大举措。 12月，比索贬值超过50%，部分缩小了官方汇率与黑市汇率之间的差距。但这推高了通货膨胀。 12 月份的降息也是如此。通常，央行会提高利率来对抗通货膨胀。该银行的理由是，降息将减少其债券的利息支付，从而减少流通量。 12 月份通货膨胀率最初飙升至 26%。 That hurt Argentines, but supercharged Mr Milei's blender.

;;

;Means matter

;

;The costs, however, are brutal.受通货膨胀的影响，估计有 50% 的阿根廷人陷入贫困，高于去年 9 月的 38%。另一家咨询公司 Invecq 计算出，按实际价值计算，工资已经倒退了 20 年。处方药的购买量下降了 7%。药房总销售额下降 46%。 1月份中小型企业的销量同比下降近30%。 The economy will shrink 4% this year, reckons Barclays, a bank.

;

;Such hardship can become dangerous for presidents, literally. 2001年，由于担心暴力抗议者，有人乘坐直升机逃离了总统办公场所卡萨罗萨达(Casa Rosada)。然而，尽管经济困难重重，米莱先生的支持率仍然非常高，达到 50% 左右。 This is mostly because he has succeeded in blaming the caste for putting Argentina in this mess.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Still, Mr Milei's first 100 days are marked by serious problems.除了痛苦之外，经济计划还充满了不确定性。其中一项风险是汇率。为了减缓通货膨胀，政府每月将比索贬值 2%。 Yet with monthly inflation much higher than 2% that is probably less than what is necessary. Alas, a faster crawl or sudden sharp devaluation would spark more inflation.

;

;Argentina will inevitably soon have to switch to a new monetary and foreign-exchange regime.问题是何时以及针对什么政权。米雷先生的计划是取消资本管制并统一汇率。但政府会推出正统的比索货币计划，还是会尝试将经济美元化？自上任以来，米雷先生关于美元化的竞选承诺变得模糊。政府现在更多地谈论“货币竞争”（允许以美元或比索进行交易）。然而，当被问及是否不考虑美元化时，财政部长巴勃罗·基尔诺 (Pablo Quirno) 模棱两可。他说，美元化是“基本上埋葬[货币]印刷机的一种方式”。这“更多的是道德讨论”。这种不确定性已经引起了投资者的不安。 The government has also hinted that it will seek a new ;IMF; programme, perhaps worth $15bn, but that too may be difficult without clearer plans.

;

;Another problem is that reducing inflation by forcing a recession will be painful.布宜诺斯艾利斯托尔夸托迪特拉大学的爱德华多·利维·耶亚蒂表示：“在一个以经济衰退为货币政策关键因素的国家进行投资没有吸引力。” What's more, he adds, when growth returns inflation could accelerate.

;

;Last, these fiscal surpluses may prove hard to sustain. 2 月份的盈余已经小于 1 月份，经济衰退正在严重打击税收收入。其中一大节省是能源补贴，但其中大部分只是推迟，而不是取消。省长们对削减转移支付表示愤怒，包括在法庭上抗议。 Although the current pension formula is helping the government reduce spending, as inflation falls it will eventually have the opposite effect.

;

;The politics have been rockiest 。米雷先生仍然很受欢迎，但他的联盟没有州长，并且在众议院仅占 15% 的席位。他于 12 月底向国会提交了一份包含 664 条文章的庞大综合法案，但遭到了拆散。最终他撤回了，这是一场惨败。缺乏优先顺序也会造成伤害。放松捕鱼许可证管制和关闭国家戏剧学院与养老金改革无关。 Yet all these and more were bundled together, slowing the bill down and providing countless reasons to vote against it.

;

;An earlier, sprawling presidential decree had the same problem.它从重要的劳动力市场放松管制延伸到次要的，允许银行对信用卡债务收取更多利息。 3 月 14 日，该法令在参议院被否决，加深了人们对米莱先生在政治上脆弱的担忧。 (The decree will remain in force unless the lower chamber also votes against it.) His labour reforms and attempts to defang unions are also tied up in the courts.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Milei has made simple errors, too.本月，反对派强调了一项由米莱签署的法令，其中包括将他的工资提高 48%——对于财政电锯的使用者来说，这是一个可怕的形象。 He said the pay rise was the result of a past president's decree, rapidly reversed it and fired his labour secretary.

;

;In the next 100 days the politics and economics will entwine.政府希望至少一个百分点的财政整顿来自于恢复所得税和其他税收改革。养老金公式也迫切需要更新。这一切都需要国会的批准。米雷先生还需要在国会取得成功，让投资者相信他有足够的盟友来避免或至少生存未来的抗议和政治混乱。他离弹劾还很远。 “There are so many bombs ticking,” says Sebastián Mazzuca of Johns Hopkins University.

;

;He appears to be aware of the problem. 3 月 1 日，他打开了围绕“五月公约”（一套自由市场原则）进行谈判的窗口。随后，他的内政部长会见了影响国会的有权有势的省长。他们中的许多人显得有些平静。一项协议可能涉及恢复一些对各省的转移支付，并恢复所得税（双方都希望但没有人愿意承认这样做），以换取向总统授予一些紧急经济权力、养老金改革以及采矿和能源放松管制。 Much else will be parked.

;

;Aesthetics of obstinance

;

;Yet it is unclear if that will be enough for Mr Milei, who still boasts he “will not cede a millimetre” on fiscal plans, and who called the senators who voted against his decree “enemies of society”.基尔诺先生声称，“无论如何”，政府都将实现其财政目标。他威胁说，如果国会阻止税收改革，政府可能会继续扣留向各省的转移支付以弥补差额。 That would be explosive.

;

;Mr Milei's fate depends on two unknowns.阿根廷人在转向他之前能承受多少经济痛苦？他能否获得足够快的经济进步所需的政治支持，以阻止整个事情崩溃？目前迹象还算积极。如果成功，他可能会在明年的中期选举中占据主导地位。然而，如果他的民调支持率首先下降，他的竞争对手肯定会挥舞着自己的电锯——反对他的计划。 And then they will try to throw his whole presidency into the blender.;■;

;;F;;ROM TIME; to time a chart circulates showing that virtually every job new in America over the past 35 years was created under a Democratic president (see chart 1). Often, the chart goes viral, and Democrats are only too happy to boast of their job-creating prowess.自 1989 年以来，椭圆形办公室的共和党人净创造了仅 130 万个就业岗位，尽管该党以对商业更加友好而闻名。 With Democrats in power a net 49.4m jobs have been added. Defined narrowly—just considering monthly employment figures—the chart is indeed accurate. But a closer look at the data paints a different picture, showing a less marked contrast.

;;
;;;
;

;Start with a simple point.如果两党命运的转变真的几乎在一夜之间给美国经济带来了如此截然不同的结果，那将是令人惊讶的。 Many things feed into growth trends that have only a scant connection to whoever is living in the White House—from the business cycle to tech innovations and Federal Reserve decisions to the global economy. At a minimum several adjustments to the jobs data are needed to make a fairer comparison.

;
;;;

;Our first adjustment is to the period of time.从 1989 年乔治·H·W·布什 (George HW Bush) 担任总统开始就扭曲了结果，因为它忽略了罗纳德·里根 (Ronald Reagan) 领导下的美国就业表现，而里根在 20 世纪 80 年代主持了经济繁荣。将美国现代经济趋势追溯到 20 世纪 70 年代末和吉米·卡特的一届总统任期更为公平（见图 2）。 This also covers a period during which Republican and Democratic parties were in the White House for roughly equal amounts of time, 24 years each. During this time Republican presidents have been in power for the creation of 17m jobs, whereas Democrats have been there for 60m. That is still a big gap (about 3.5 times as many jobs were created under Democrats as under Republicans) but not as large as the chasm that appears if the analysis starts in 1989 (a ratio of 39 to one).

;对第一个图表的另一个反对意见是运气造成了很大的差异（参见图 3）。乔治·W·布什既没有造成 2000 年代初的互联网泡沫破灭，也没有造成 2007-09 年的全球金融危机，但它们却结束了他的总统任期。两者都摧毁了数百万个就业岗位。老布什则抱怨——他有一定道理——在他入主白宫期间，过于鹰派的美联储破坏了经济。唐纳德·特朗普不应为新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 大流行最严重时期的大规模失业负责。 Moreover, after several of the downturns that weighed on Republican job figures, big rebounds flattered Democratic totals.

;

;A better way to examine differences is to look at the median month for job creation in each presidency, thereby eliminating any unusually weak or strong期间。以这种方式分析，里根和特朗普以微弱优势击败了巴拉克·奥巴马，尽管两人都远远落后于乔·拜登迄今为止的记录（见图 4）。 On the whole Democratic presidents still do better than Republicans do, but the margin is greatly reduced (to about two to one).

;Another sensible adjustment to evaluating the job performance under each president is to apply a one-year lag.这里的逻辑是，总统需要一段时间才能站稳脚跟，开始制定政策——从行政命令到立法——定义他们的政治遗产。特朗普在上任第一年接近尾声时将全面减税法案签署为法律。拜登先生以新冠复苏刺激措施起步更快。但他的其他重大举措，包括基础设施投资计划，却花了更长的时间才获得通过。 And companies, individuals and investors need even more time to digest policy shifts.

;Looking at median monthly job creation in each presidency, lagged by one year, Mr Biden holds on to the top spot.但特朗普紧随其后，排名第二，里根排名第三。总体而言，民主党的表现仍然优于共和党，但差距再次比以前小得多：民主党每月就业岗位中位数为 205,000 个，而共和党为 150,000 个（见图 5）。对于民主党来说，这一数字仍然高出 40% 左右——这是一个相当大的差距。但在美国这样一个庞大而多元化的经济体中，有如此多的外生变量在起作用，将这种差异归咎于白宫主人就有些牵强了。 Still, one thing is clear: Republicans are far off base when they brand their opponents as job killers.;■;

;;F;;or; ;most; of this century it has looked as if the world's economy was turning Japanese, with low growth, below-target inflation and rock-bottom interest rates. Today the question is how much Japan will come to look like the rest of the world. On March 19th the Bank of Japan ;raised interest rates; for the first time since 2007, after inflation seemed at last to have become entrenched. Interest on balances held at the bank, previously set at minus 0.1%, will now be plus 0.1%. The central bank, under its relatively new governor, Ueda Kazuo (pictured), also scrapped its policy of yield-curve control, which capped long-term bond yields at 1%. Having kept monetary policy ultra-loose for years, Japan has now begun to follow the course set by other economies since widespread inflation took hold.

;

;It is a remarkable moment. Before 2022 annual inflation had been above 2% for only 12 of the previous 120 months; today it has been above that level for 22 consecutive months.日本最大的企业最近同意将工资提高 5.3%，这一水平在全球通胀爆发之前是不可想象的。 There is a sense that change is here to stay. Stocks have been ;booming;—the Nikkei 225 recently passed its December 1989 record—and investors are optimistic about the economy.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yet it would be wrong to conclude that Japan is de-Japanifying.比一个经济体的名义属性（如通货膨胀、总体利率和股市增长）更重要的是其真实的结构性特征。 If you look at the fundamentals, even the rise in interest rates is not quite what it seems. The 2% inflation target which the Bank of Japan believes is now in sight is 1.4 percentage points higher than the average inflation rate over the ten years to the end of 2021. This 1.4-point rise in expected inflation towers over the 0.2-point rise in interest rates, which in real terms have therefore fallen, not risen. Moreover, the bank made clear in its statement on March 19th that it expected to maintain “accommodative” financial conditions and would keep buying some bonds.

;

;Rock-bottom real rates reflect the fact that Japan's elderly population—30% are over 65—has abundant savings. Companies struggle to put these to productive use, because an economy with a shrinking population has a lower appetite for capital investment.日本的人口结构和不愿允许大量移民也限制了其增长。 The ;IMF; expects average annual; gdp ;growth of just 0.5% over the next four years, compared with 2% in America. That is a respectable pace given the lack of workers—growth in output per worker has long been healthy. But it is hardly a resurgence.

;

;A final factor is Japan's enduring public indebtedness. The debt-to-;GDP; ratio is 255% in gross terms, or 159% after netting off the government's financial assets; both measures are the highest in the rich world. Even with low interest rates, nearly 9% of the government budget is spent on debt interest. Japan could not withstand a monetary tightening anything like as severe as the one in America, where rates have reached 5.25-5.5%.

;

;Long before they got to such levels in Japan, the government would have to reduce its deficit, which was 5.6% of ;GDP; in 2023. The economy would cool from fiscal belt-tightening, not higher rates. With monetary policy, as with growth, there remains only one path by which Japan will cease to be exceptional: if the rest of the world comes to resemble it. ;■;

; ;;O ZHE WANG; at ;Google DeepMind;, an artificial-intelligence (;AI;) company, corner kicks are like games of chess. Partly because both feature opposing sides poised to react to a single imminent move. But also, no doubt, because they may also one day be revolutionised by ;AI;.

;

;;AI; models ;thrive where there is abundant data;. Football more than satisfies this requirement. Elite players wear vests that measure heart rate, position, speed and force exerted; team analysts watch hours of footage to tally possession percentages and numbers of passes, shots and goals. In a paper published on March 19th in ;Nature Communications;, Mr Wang and his colleagues worked with staff at Liverpool Football Club to feed this data into a statistical model known as a graph neural network (;GNN;). They then were able to use this model to predict which on-field player would wind up making first contact with the ball with similar accuracy to human experts.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Coaches around the world should be pacing in front of their dugouts in excitement at the news. During a football match's standard 90 minutes, it is rare to encounter the same situation twice. But corner kicks, which are eminently repeatable, are the focus of hours of specialist training. And doing well in them pays off. Arsenal, sitting at the top of the Premier League when this research paper was published, have scored 13 goals from corners out of a season total of 70. Small advantages in this part of the game can make a big difference.

;

;DeepMind's ;GNN ;works by establishing statistical relationships between data collected from all 22 players during 7,176 corner kicks. Each corner routine was eventually represented as a vector in a 352-dimensional space: impossible for a human to visualise, but easy for a computer to process. Corners that unfolded similarly wound up close together in that space, allowing the model to make predictions about new set pieces.

;

;The model was also capable of using this analysis to suggest new tactics. And, based on ratings from five experts from Liverpool, ;AI;-generated corner-kick tactics were just as good as those suggested by human coaches. In fact, shown 50 pairs of corners, one real and one with an ;AI;-suggested improvement, 90% of the ;AI; suggestions found favour with the majority of judges.

;

;Mr Wang, who confesses he is “no football fan”, says that the sport offers a safe and controllable test bed to develop assistive ;AI ;technologies that might one day be used in health care or defence. After all, football is not a matter of life and death. It is, as Bill Shankly, a former Liverpool manager, once observed, much more important than that. ;■;

;;I;; GREW UP; in an India that was a proud liberal democracy saddled with an illiberal, over-regulated economy that micro-managed private enterprise.我们称之为许可证管理。我在一家生产 Vicks VapoRub 的公司工作。有一年，流感流行，维克斯的销量猛增。年底，政府发出传票，声称我的公司违反了法律：销量超过了我们许可证中授权的维克斯产量。 It was a criminal offence, we were told.

;

;I was asked to appear at a hearing before a government official.我解释说，疫情造成了额外的需求；我们只是在尽我们的职责，保持商店货架上的库存。但官员宣布我们有罪，并宣布法律现在将按其程序进行。 As I got up to leave, I asked the official to imagine how our country would look to the world when news broke that our government had punished someone for alleviating the misery of millions during an epidemic.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In the end, the government quietly dropped the case. But I abandoned socialism to become a classical liberal and joined the liberal Swatantra Party. Liberalism offered me a philosophy that champions human progress that does not expect it to come solely from the state. I learned to believe in the liberal virtues of openness, mutual respect and tolerance of others' views.

;

;India had to wait until the liberalisation of 1991 to win its economic freedom, after sacrificing two generations to missed opportunities. I wrote a book, “India Unbound”, predicting the rise of India based on the reforms. India obliged by becoming the world's second-fastest-growing large economy, expanding at an average annual rate of almost 6% over the next 30 years, lifting 400m people out of poverty and expanding the middle class from 10% to 30% of the population.

;

;But just when everything seemed to be going well, democracy began to weaken. The past decade has seen the rise of identity politics, majoritarianism, Hindu nationalism and Islamophobia. Critics are being silenced and discourse on social media has become a weapon of the right. The atmosphere of hate has damaged India's cherished secular ideal of ;sarva dharma samabhava, ;respect for all religions. Although there has been no communal riot on the same scale as those in Gujarat in 2002 or in Delhi in 1984, there have been many localised incidents of violence, not least against Muslims suspected of selling beef.

;

;Today, Indian liberals like me face a dilemma: not only do we have no one to vote for, but even if we did they would be unelectable. It can feel like a lonely road. I lost my friends on the right when I publicly condemned the riots in Gujarat and criticised the banknote demonetisation in 2016 by the government, led then, as now, by the Bharatiya Janata Party (;BJP;). I lost my friends on the left when I voted for the ;BJP; in 2014.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Sadly, I am the man in the middle, disappointed with both sides. I cannot vote for the authoritarian, identity politics of the BJP. But I also do not trust the redistributive, populist and statist economics of the opposition Congress party, ever ready to make a false trade-off between growth and equity. Nor do I have much faith in the ;INDIA; alliance of opposition parties that was formed last year with Congress at its centre.

;

;Lamentably, in the past ten years the opposition has not come up with a single new idea to deal with most of India's biggest issues: jobs, air quality, education and health care. Handing out pocket money to women in Karnataka or free bus rides in Delhi will not cut it. The ;INDIA; alliance is incapable of doing the heavy lifting to take the economy to the next level.

;

;India may have become a fast-growing economy but it has still not created enough jobs. It has failed to create an industrial revolution. Manufacturing accounts for only 17% of ;GDP; and India punches well below its weight when it comes to exports of industrial goods. It needs to find more productive jobs for the 45% of its workers stuck in agriculture.

;

;But how? It will require major reforms, including three that Narendra Modi's ;BJP; government tried but failed to enact because of the lack of opposition support: simplifying the acquisition of land for industrial purposes; modifying rigid labour laws to give companies flexibility to hire and lay off workers while protecting them from exploitation; and overhauling farm laws to improve productivity. I trust the ;BJP; to execute these reforms far more than the opposition—though the BJP, while a party of modernisation, is not an ideological reformer.

;

;Liberals are partly to blame for this unhappy state of affairs. One reason is that liberalism in India remains an elite enterprise: the rise of Hindu nationalism is partly a revolt against the English-speaking elite. Another reason is that no liberal political leader has had a serious dialogue with tradition. Mahatma Gandhi, alas, died too soon. He had been able to translate the liberal ideas of liberty and equality into the civilisational language of ;dharma;—his moral principles—and thus capture the hearts and minds of the masses.

;

;And yet, despite this gloomy situation, I remain optimistic about liberalism's future in India. India's civilisational temper is open, inclusive and liberal. In a land of 330m gods where no god can afford to feel jealous, and where people are argumentative, narrow Hindu nationalism is unlikely to have a long shelf life. Liberalism will win out in the end.;■;
